Can every integer $N\geq 2$ be written as\[N=\frac{\prod_{1\leq i\leq k}(m+i)}{\prod_{1\leq i\leq k}(n+i)}\]for some $k\geq 2$ and $m\geq n+k$?



If $n$ and $k$ are fixed then can one say anything about the set of integers so represented?

See also [677].


Back to the problem

currentState.focus: Problem formalized with Representation structure. Answer is OPEN.

knowledge.progressSummary: SURVEYED: Formalized ratio of consecutive products problem. Representation structure defined. Problem is OPEN.
insights: Constraint m ≥ n + k ensures products are disjoint and ratio ≥ 1
Equivalent to asking about ratios of binomial coefficients
Related to Problem 677 on lcm of consecutive integers
Small cases (like N=6) can be verified: (3·4)/(1·2) = 6 with k=2
nextSteps: Computational search for representations of small N
Explore connection to Problem 677 on lcm
